results.title: Yankee doodle dandy
results.creator_credit: Michael Curtiz, William Cagney and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: George B. Cohan, born on the 4th of July, became one of Broadway’s legendary composers. Cohan’s prolific career spanned 55 years where he wrote 35 plays and 500 songs including “Harrigan”, “Give my regards to Broadway”, and of course “Yankee Doodle Dandy.” This is an exuberant song and dance production starring James Cagney, with his typical flair, in the title role. This film premiered in 1942 and was a salute to American patriotism and the ‘Grand old flag’, yet time has not dulled its freshness and energy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Curtiz, William Cagney and Warner Bros Pictures

results.title: You can't take it with you
results.brief_description: Meet the Vanderhofs - the zaniest, happiest family ever to grace the screen. They have a simple philosophy for living “Nothing is worth doing if you can’t enjoy it - and when it’s over you can’t take it with you”. Head of this eccentric clan is Grandpa, (Lionel Barrymore) who has decided to devote the rest of his life to having fun because he has enough money. Matters become complicated when his granddaughter (Jean Arthur) falls in love with James Stewart, son of a tycoon (Edward Arnold), who wants the Vanderhof property to expand his business. Wholesome, homespun, appealing and touching this screwball Capra comedy won two Academy Awards in 1938 for Best Picture and Best Direction.

results.title: There's no business like show business
results.creator_credit: Walter Lang, Sol Siegel and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: An all-star cast that includes Ethel Merman, Dan Dailey, Marilyn Monroe, Donald O’Connor, Johnnie Ray and Mitzi Gaynor, sparks this tuneful Irving Berlin musical depicting the trials and triumphs of a veteran vaudeville family. Molly and Terry Donahue start out as a duo and keep adding kids to their stage act until they finally become the 5 Donahues. Their busy, sometimes tumultuous lives aren’t always easy, but the Donahues have plenty of love to get them through the hard times and more than enough talent to keep them on top. Highlighted by one classic Irving Berlin song after another and an array of dazzling production numbers, this upbeat, utterly delightful tale of life on the stage proves, beyond any doubt that there is no business like show business!

results.title: The Mummy
results.creator_credit: Karl Freund, Carl Laemmle and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Boris Karloff’s role in the 1932 version of The Mummy has become a landmark in the annals of screen history. Karloff plays Im-Ho-Tep, the mummy, who is accidently revived after 3,700 years by a British archaeology team. In flashback, we find that he was a high priest who was embalmed alive for trying to revive the vestel virgin whom he loved after she had been sacrificed. Now, dressed in the garb of a modern day Egyptian, he sets out to find his lost love, mistaking Helen Grosvenor (Zita Johann) for her and terrorizing the expedition members who must find a way to stop him. Today, almost half a century after its production, this brooding, dream-like film remains a horror masterpiece. Also stars David Manners, Bramwell Fletcher, Arthur Byron and Edward Van Sloan. Based on a story by Nina Wilcox Putnam and Richard Schayer.

results.title: Fail safe
results.creator_credit: Sidney Lumet, Max Youngstein and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: A tense and suspenseful peice of filmmaking dealing with the frightening implications of accidental nuclear warfare. It faithfully translates to the screen the power and seething drama of the Eugene Burdick-Harvey Wheeler book of the same name. What if a computer malfunction was to set off events possibly resulting in a nuclear war? This is the basic premise of the gripping narrative that is realistically and almost frighteningly told as the US attempts to halt the plane carrying the bombs which has been sent to deploy its deadly cargo on the Russians when America’s complex defence system mistakes an off-course airliner for a hostile enemy plane and the sophisticated fail-safe device malfunctions. As time runs out and a global holocaust seems imminent, the President (Henry Fonda) is faced with implementing an appalling peace offering. It would be an interesting exercise to compare this film with “Dr. Strangelove” as both films deal with the same premise, which led to claims of plagiarism when “Failsafe” was originally released.

results.title: Ball of fire
results.creator_credit: Howard Hawks, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Company
results.brief_description: Gary Cooper takes centre stage in “Ball of fire” together with Barbara Stanwyck in Howard Hawks’ deliciously funny, and delightful romantic comedy. Cooper is a serious English professor working with his intellectual collegues on a dictionary of American slang. Stanwyck, a red-hot nightclub singer, on the run from the mob, seeks refuge in their house and finds a place in their hearts. Soon, the professor and his friends learn a lot about language and life, and Cooper and Stanwyck prove that the world of semantics is big enough for two who can speak the language of love.

results.title: Dead ringers
results.creator_credit: David Cronenberg, Mark Boyman and Rank Film Productions
results.brief_description: Jeremy Irons plays the dual role of Elliott and Beverley Mantle, two genius twin gynaecologists. The twins share all aspects of their lives, including their work, sexual partners and social circle. When one of them falls in love, this creates a disturbance in both of their psychologies which is horribly acted out in their medical experimentation on women. David Cronenberg has directed some of modern cinema’s most effective horror films but “Dead Ringers” is possibly his masterpiece being a terrifying nightmare that examines the monsters in our own psyches. A startling, disturbing film that confronts the male and female viewer with our basest fears of misogyny, birth and sexuality. Co-starring Genevieve Bujold and based on the book “Twins” by Bari Wood and Jack Geasland.

results.title: The Young lions
results.creator_credit: Edward Dmytryk, Al Lightman and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The Young Lions depicts the individual men and women on both sides of World War II. On the American side, two men struggle to endure the hardships of Boot Camp and the struggle to reclaim France. On the German side, a dedicated officer goes from the victories of the early years to the despair of defeat. Inevitably, the two sides are drawn together for the showdown. Marlon Brando dominates the film as the young German idealist who embraces Nazism but later comes to doubt it. The film also stars Montgomery Clift, Dean Martin, Hope Lange, Barbara Rush and May Britt. Based on the novel by Irwin Shaw.

results.title: The Gauntlet
results.creator_credit: Clint Eastwood, Robert Daley, Malpaso Company and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Clint Eastwood runs ‘The Gauntlet’ into an explosive piece of movie making that lives up to its title with a vengeance. He plays a burnt out Phoenix cop on an assignment to bring back from Las Vegas a ‘nothing witness for a nothing trial’ (Locke) which seems just another meaningless task in a meaningless life. Until the fireworks start! Trapped by treachery on both sides of the law, the two are forced through a deadly obstacle course of raging gunfire, blazing cars, swooping helicopters, murderous ambushes, crazed bikers and crooked police. With non-stop action and special effects that will blast you to the back of your seat, including a ferocious finale in which an armoured bus is shot to smithereens with more than 8,000 bullets (8000 bullets and none hit the tyres!). Leave the driving to Eastwood, sit back and enjoy the ride.

results.title: The Country girl
results.creator_credit: George Seaton, William Perlberg and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Grace Kelly received an Oscar for her brilliant portrayal of the wife, and Bing Crosby gave one of the most outstanding performances of his career as an alcoholic, guilt-ridden has-been. When he is given an opportunity to star in a new musical show, his wife (Grace Kelly) and the show’s director (William Holden) attempt to bolster his ego and help him make a comeback. This superb drama, based on Clifford Odet’s play, was nominated for seven Academy Awards.
